this is a big deal for speedrunning, please mojang, please add it back. Why remove a feature that was actively being used. The mods that are supposed to "add this functionality back" are not working too. Take BetterF3 for example, F3+F does change the render distance but not actually load new chunks, until we go to settings and press escape (probably because of a event firing when we escape out of minecraft options) that the mod makers missed. The point is, add it back, i beg u

Very late, but I thought about what you said, and I think I remember experiencing the same thing when I used BetterF3 in 1.19 (and maybe even 1.20.4?) on servers. F3+F technically changed the render distance but never actually updated until I opened the game menu and escaped. I also just discovered that F3+F had existed for over a decade even before 1.9 but was temporarily removed in 1.7.2 when the render distance slider was changed to have more options. Knowing this makes its removal a bit more disappointing...

This would be especially useful on Java edition as well! Love the idea, but would like to see it in both versions, as Java doesn’t have a reliable variable system. Also a couple of suggestions:


1. Instead of /getvar and /setvar, it should be /variable get and /variable set (could be shortened to just /var

2. There should be operations to these variables, eg /var operation [value]. (For example, /var operation exampleInteger addition 5, or /var operation exampleString join “Hello”)

3. Some more types of variable: Boolean (stores True or False), Date (stores a date), Time (stores a time)

This would be awesome. The amount of uses and purposes this could serve in command projects would be crazy.

For coordinates, I think it would be nice to specify which to save as variables with arguments. And a way to include these in commands such as teleport and summon would be insanely useful.

I hope to see this in the game sometime in the future. :]

This would fix a lot of headaches!

Variables and data storage are already available in a variety of forms—it's up to you to decide which is the best for the job.

For numerical formats, scoreboards are the best tool because they support mathematical operations like +, −, ×,÷, and modulus (%).

If you need to store strings, the probably best way is to use Minecraft's built in free store:

/data merge storage namespace:myarea {MyString:'this is a test string'}

There are probably other ways to store data too, like by setting blocks in your world, or modifying item data.

My mod list included one that makes it so mobs (besides sieges because game design....) only spawn in covered 0 light making it so even at night mobs can only spawn in caves, dark forests, under overhangs etc. The effect being that dark forests, jungles and caves are more dangerous than vanilla but open areas are generally safe but still the chance a creeper could be hiding in the one 0 light spot under some trees waiting for night.

Our last world was almost perfect.... expect for sieges. And really.... the problem isn't having that mechanic as an option it's not being able to turn it off or easily circumvent it like EVERYTHING ELSE.

You can already create this with existing features, but I can see why you would want this and why it wouldn't make sense to not have this tag.
Yeah, it's kinda annoying that they combined them, as it breaks a few early 1.16 datapacks that use this tag. Hopefully they can at least separate it into different tags.
I share that idea but scheduling should work with commands and functions and not instead of functions as you wrote.

Letting it work for commands would also still let it work for functions, since a possible command is /function NAME.

I agree, this is a great idea. Although I think the syntax would be better as

/schedule [command|clear] command <time> [append|replace] <custom-id>, where the custom-id is used in the schedule clear <id> half of the schedule function.

I think this could make the schedule command extremely useful (as of right now it is very useful also, it just encourages a lot of tiny otherwise-useless functions so that small events can be scheduled).

Yes please. It is great that we got a schedule command. That makes rather complicated setups to get some sort of delay or time control irrelevant.

But it should work with commands as well. Sometimes I just want to delay a very specific vanilla command (e.g. something stupid like "say hi") and have to set up a whole function in order to accomplish that. That inflates my already bloated function folder more.
Bedrock already has this, as /event
This would be awesome. If we can have the ability to schedule both, we can benefit from running functions on a schedule, as well as not having to make a new function to schedule a singular command!

Also Bedrock has the /mobevent command, so should we. It would help immensely with this issue.

Hey was this for Java or Bedrock, as I want this command on bedrock,

认同，目前 schedule 函数不允许通过宏传入参数，对于数据包开发者，这会为他们整合大量重复函数带来极大的困难。允许 schedule 使用宏将会使他们获得便利。

因此， 根据楼主的说法，schedule 使用 function 时的语法应该是：

schedule function <function> {Param1:... , Param2:... , ...} <time> [append/replace]

我个人有一种更加理想的方案。改变 schedule 的语法，若要通过它执行一些东西，先通过 delay 声明执行的延迟（作用是与 clear 区分开，避免语法混淆），同时将 function 更名为 run ， 允许其直接执行一个指令，通过指令执行 function 也能达到对宏的使用。同时，还能做到延时检查目标状态等复杂的功能。

此外，在run的基础下增添一个可选的tag选项，以此标记所执行的延时计划，方便 schedule clear语句清除计划。

 

因此，个人理想中的语法如下：

schedule delay <time> [append/replace] [tag <tagName> [tag <tagName> [...]]] run <command>
schedule clear <tagName>

此外，个人还有几个例子对该语法加以解释说明：

#在1秒钟后对函数传参并执行
schedule delay 1s run function foo:bar {param1:... , param2:...}

#在10游戏刻后输出helloworld，并为语句添加 test 标记
schedule delay 10t tag test run say helloworld

#在20游戏刻后嵌套一个新的schedule，执行函数，并为第一个schedule添加test和example标记
schedule delay 20t tag example tag test run schedule delay 10t run function foo:bar

#在5游戏刻后检查最近玩家的谓词（假设为holding_sword），若执行成功，清除标记为test的语句
schedule delay 5t run execute as @n if predicate holding_sword run schedule clear test

#这些例子都表明了该函数语法的功能强大。而且该语法具有很强的可扩展性，未来的更新还可以在tag、run、delay的基础上增加更多的语法规则

I'll second this post because of the ability to have it all in one function. In the meantime we could have a check before each step of the inner function:

execute as @e[type=cow] at @s run say Step 1
execute as @e[type=cow] at @s run say Step 2

But it is much more cumbersome to write and it messes up the collation of the steps, so that's why I agree with this post.

I'm afraid I don't agree with the syntax for blocks though, braces {} seem too far deviated from Minecraft command syntax. Instead of that, I'd like to propose indentation blocks like in the language Python to show this. Indent should be one tab per indentation level. This renders as eight spaces here but many notepad editors allow customization:

execute if <condition> run commands
	say Hello world!
	give @s minecraft:diamond 64
execute as @e[type=minecraft:cow] at @s run commands
	data modify entity @s Motion[1] set value 5.0f
	particle minecraft:cloud ~ ~ ~ 0 0 0 0.1 10 normal

The word commands can be anything, but it is required because I think you should be required to indicate when you are about to start an indented block, and a key word that activates it would best fit in with current command syntax.

As for word choice, I thought of something that would make sense if you said it out loud (… if this condition is true, run the commands …) and I didn't want to use function because it was already taken. Feel free to suggest another word.

On the error bit, maybe the game should calculate if it is possible, and if it isn't, then raise an error. also, there should be a detour argument which is set to false automatically, and makes the mob walk around the obstacle if true instead of just walking straight into it then slowly moving to the side if at an angle.

Hmmmm, I cordially disagree. The armor in Java will provide significant reduction, but balance out with toughness; getting weaker the more toughness (effect resist) you have. In Bedrock armor caps at 80% damage mitigation regardless. And that’s before you have enchants. Now armor has no effect on starving, drowning, suffocating, burning, void, magic & then some. These are all preparedness & common sense checks; like digging down. It would be interesting to see bedrock conform to Java; toughness randomly (or a method to a madness) to different armor drops dropped in different manners.
If they do this, they should also allow an increase for the max value of the generic.armor attribute.
